description: Uncertain. Occurs in print at least as early as 1831, when Samuel Lover used the expression as one already long-established. He unambiguously stated the derivation of cess in the malediction bad cess to be an abbreviation of success.. OED speculated that it either was from success or from assessment meaning a military or governmental exaction.

entries.meaning: (Britain, Ireland) An assessed tax, duty, or levy.
(Britain, Ireland, informal) Usually preceded by good or (more commonly) bad: luck or success.

verbs.description: cess (third-person singular simple present cesses, present participle cessing, simple past and past participle cessed)

description: Possibly from an archaic dialect word meaning “bog”. According to the OED, from earlier suspiral (“water pipe, setting tank”).

entries.meaning: (rail transport) The area along either side of a railroad track which is kept at a lower level than the sleeper bottom, in order to provide drainage.
(obsolete, dialect) A bog, in particular a peat bog.
(obsolete, dialect) A piece of peat, or a turf, particularly when dried for use as fuel.

verbs.description: cess (third-person singular simple present cesses, present participle cessing, simple past and past participle cessed)
